discussion.content:
C. Teams display

Explanation:
Teams Display devices are designed to work independently of the user's computer and can support calls, video, speed dial, and display chat history.
Teams Rooms are more suited for meeting spaces and not personal desks.
Teams-certified handsets primarily support calls, but typically do not support video or display chat history.
Teams panels are used for scheduling and managing meeting spaces, not for personal use on a desk.
Therefore, a Teams display is the appropriate device to meet all the specified requirements.

questions.question_text:
You are deploying Microsoft Teams Phone.

You need to provide a user with a device on his desk that can be used when the user's computer is turned off. The device must meet the following requirements:

• Support calls.
• Support video.
• Support speed dial.
• Display chat history.

Which type of device should you provide?

You have a Microsoft Teams Phone deployment and a Survivable Branch Appliance (SBA) at a site.

You add a new Teams user.

You need to ensure that the user at the site can place and receive PSTN calls in the event of an internet outage.

What should you do?

choices.C: Modify the online voice routing policy.
choices.B: Add the user as a member of a call queue.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
The Survivable Branch Appliance (SBA) provides a local gateway for users when there is a disruption in the internet connection to the cloud, ensuring that users can still place and receive PSTN calls. However, for a user to take advantage of the SBA during such an outage, they need to be assigned the appropriate Survivable Branch Appliance (SBA) policy, which is done using the Grant-CsTeamsSurvivableBranchAppliancePolicy cmdlet. This policy ensures that the user is registered to the SBA in case of an internet failure, allowing them to make and receive calls through the local appliance.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP
-

You need to provision a Microsoft Teams-certified common area phone device at a field site. The solution must ensure that a standard user can complete the physical handset tasks without sharing credentials.

Which four actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
D is wrong becuase the output shows MCOEV which is phone sys license assigned.

comments.content: sorry, B is to fill the LineUri parameter

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
A:This assigns a phone number to User1, which is necessary for the dial pad to appear.
B: This ensures that User1 has Enterprise Voice enabled, which is required for the dial pad to be visible.

Selected Answer: AC
Agreeing with the other comments. A & C are correct. As VSARAVAN pointed out, D is incorrect because they already have a Teams Phone Standard license (MCOEV). https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/entra/identity/users/licensing-service-plan-reference

Selected Answer: AC
The correct answers are A and C. Assigning a number resets the EnterpriseVoiceEnable flag to True and VoiceRoutingPolicy should provide a route to Gateway.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/teams/set-csphonenumberassignment?view=teams-ps#:~:text=%3CBoolean%3E%0A%20%20%20%5B%3CCommonParameters%3E%5D-,Description,-This%20cmdlet%20assigns

choices.A: Run the Set-CsPhoneNumberAssignment cmdlet and specify the -PhoneNumber parameter.
choices.D: Assign a Microsoft Teams Phone Standard license to User1.
choices.B: Run the Set-CsUser cmdlet and specify the -LineURI parameter.
